node.title: Blenheim waste dumping charges to rise as new greenwaste weighbridges near
node.description: Marlborough's waste dumping charges are set to increase, as the Government tries to encourage people to dump less.

node.title: Composting initiative to ‘supercharge’ Māngere marae’s good works
node.description: A south Auckland marae is establishing a community compost collection service intended in part to help young people learn about sustainability.

node.title: Will the government’s massive Māngere housing project repeat past mistakes?
node.description: Plans to build 10,000 new houses in Māngere may help solve Auckland's housing shortage, but many fear it will gentrify the suburb in the process.

node.title: Tasman ratepayers may cover $20m in Waimea Dam excess costs
node.description: Ratepayers in Tasman may have to cover the cost of the Waimea Dam's latest $20 million overrun.

node.title: Vegetables may be 'priced off the table' without Government action - HortNZ
node.description: Horticulture New Zealand says vegetable prices will continue to rise if the government doesn't support growers to reduce costs.

node.title: Top of the south orchards seek to replenish workforce
node.description: A campaign to attract seasonal workers to the horticulture and viticulture industries in Nelson Tasman has recruited several hundred people, but many orchards in the top of the south are still looking…

node.title: Earthquake jolts Japan's northeast coast
node.description: A powerful magnitude 7.3 earthquake jolted Japan's northeast coast off Fukushima, leaving one person dead and 69 injured.

node.title: Dr. Oz says he will renounce his Turkish citizenship if elected to Senate
node.description: The announcement came after one of his top rivals pressed the issue.

node.title: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe and Anoosheh Ashoori on way home to UK
node.description: British-Iranian nationals Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe and Anoosheh Ashoori will be reunited with their families in the UK after being freed from Iran after five years.

node.title: PM launches new history curriculum, discusses Covid-19 settings
node.description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern and Ministers Kelvin Davis, Jan Tinetti, and Aupito William Sio launched the Aotearoa New Zealand histories curriculum at Sylvia Park School.

node.title: Covid-19 immunity level tests to go on sale at pharmacies
node.description: New Zealanders wanting to know how protected they are against Covid-19 infection could soon be able to have their immunity levels measured at their local pharmacy. Audio

node.title: Shargin Stephens shooting: Police bail checks were ‘oppressive’ - IPCA
node.description: In a major u-turn, the police watchdog has found constant, late-night checks on Shargin Stephens were unreasonable and may have contributed to him lashing out, before police fatally shot him.

node.title: Fonterra reports profit fall as higher milk prices raised costs
node.description: The dairy giant's net profit for the six months ended January was $364 million, down 7 percent on last year.

node.title: More than 100 arrested in Florida human trafficking sting, police say
node.description: Authorities arrested 108 people, including alleged child sexual predators and those seeking prostitutes.

node.title: Chance encounter at lemonade stand reconnects family who evacuated from Ukraine
node.description: American diplomats evacuated their children to California amid the war in Ukraine. A chance encounter reconnected them.

node.title: Trucking industry feels pain of rising diesel prices
node.description: The steep prices are trickling down through the economy.

node.title: Court orders Jussie Smollett released from jail during appeal
node.description: Smollett was sentenced last week to 30 months felony probation, including 150 days in jail.

node.title: Convicted murderer makes fresh bid to clear name, victim still not found
node.description: Twenty years after Nicholas Pike was murdered, his body hasn't been found and the man convicted of killing him is still trying to clear his name, Jimmy Ellingham reports.

node.title: Ukraine joins European power grid, ending its dependence on Russia
node.description: Grid operators had been preparing such a move after Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014.

node.title: Wellington water missing fluoride for six weeks
node.description: A Wellington City councillor is furious they were not told a large swathe of the capital's drinking water has not been fluoridated for six weeks.

node.title: Covid-19: Families skipping funerals during outbreak
node.description: Grieving families are being urged to embrace the ritual power of a funeral after Covid-19 lockdowns denied many people in-person goodbyes.

node.title: Iran releases 2 British citizens jailed for over 5 years
node.description: The breakthrough came as world leaders try to negotiate​ the return of both Iran and the U.S. to an international agreement on Tehran's nuclear program.

node.title: US Federal Reserve hikes interest rates, signals aggressive fight against inflation
node.description: The US central bank has raised interest rates for the first time in more than three years and signalled more aggressive hikes through the year to tackle inflation.

node.title: DOJ settles Parkland school shooting civil cases for $127.5 million
node.description: Over 40 civil cases were filed against the Department of Justice following the 2018 shooting.

node.title: Covid-19: Bloomfield expecting Auckland hospitalisations to decline
node.description: The Director-General of Health says Auckland's hospital cases have likely peaked, but he thinks the hospitalisation number will creep above 1000 as the rest of the country catches up. Audio

node.title: New Zealand round of Sail GP confirmed
node.description: New Zealand will makes it's debut on the Sail GP calendar this time next year.

node.title: Covid-19 continues to ravage Super Rugby
node.description: Only one domestic Super Rugby Pacific game will go ahead this weekend as Covid-19 continues to ravage the competition.

node.title: Iwi lead panacea process as Parliament grounds reopen
node.description: The House: A cool, bleak midweek morning in Wellington is not everyone's cup of tea, but for the community who live and work in and around Parliament, today's ceremony was welcome and restorative. Audio

node.title: What's happening with coffee prices?
node.description: Coffee prices in Australia are going through the roof, but could the same thing happen in New Zealand? Audio

node.title: Pensioner told to repay $11,300 because she could not get back to NZ
node.description: A 77-year-old woman who was stuck in Australia because of border restrictions says she feels hurt at her pension being stopped and receiving a demand to repay more than $11,000.
